definitions.sensetop: anticipate somethinganticipate doing somethinganticipate something doing somethinganticipate that…it is anticipated that…

examples.text: We don't anticipate any major problems.
The eagerly anticipated movie will be released next month.
They anticipate moving to bigger premises by the end of the year.
I don't anticipate it being a problem.
We anticipate that sales will rise next year.
It is anticipated that inflation will stabilize at 3 per cent.
The band today announced details of their widely anticipated third album.
The dog sat up, anticipating a biscuit.

definitions.definition: to see what might happen in the future and take action to prepare for it
definitions.sensetop: anticipate somethinganticipate what, how, that, etc…

examples.text: We need someone who can anticipate and respond to changes in the fashion industry.
Try and anticipate what the interviewers will ask.

definitions.definition: to think with pleasure and excitement about something that is going to happen

examples.text: We eagerly anticipated the day we would leave school.
The more I anticipated arriving somewhere, the more disappointed I was.

definitions.definition: to do something before it can be done by somebody else

examples.text: When Scott reached the South Pole he found that Amundsen had anticipated him.

wordOrigin: mid 16th cent. (in the senses ‘to take something into consideration’, ‘mention something before the proper time’): from Latin anticipat- ‘acted in advance’, from anticipare, based on ante- ‘before’ + capere ‘take’.
